misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Correct Implementation with Minor Input/Output Flow Improvement Needed
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that reading input elements requires a loop separate from the shifting logic, correctly defines an array 'a', saves the last element 'b', and then uses a decreasing index loop (i=n-1 down to 1) to perform the right shift (a[i] = a[i-1]). Finally, they assign the saved last element 'b' to the first position a[0]. This mental model of array shifting is correct.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no fundamental conceptual gap regarding the array shifting mechanism. The student correctly handles the variable initialization, input reading, temporary storage of the wrapping element, shifting loop, and assignment of the wrapped element. The logic is sound and correctly implements the required array rotation.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No output error (The code produces the correct output for the problem statement.)
